Icon module for Nuxt with 100,000+ ready to use icons from Iconify.
Support 200,000 open source vector icons via

npm install --save-dev nuxt-icon

# Using yarn
yarn add --dev nuxt-icon
That's it, you can now use the
✨ If you are using VS Code, you can use the
(required): icon name, emoji or global component name

component in a render function (useful if you create a functional component), for this you can import it from

This is currently experimental and may change in the future, this is a way to use CSS icons instead of SVG icons to reduce the DOM size and improve performance. It is leveraging the Mask combined with background color set to
, useful to render monotone icons that use
as icon color. Learn more on
Note that CSS Masks have limited support, see
Also, the icons won't be loaded on initial load and an HTTP request will be made to Iconify CDN to load them.

html .light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html.light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}
